title: Terminator: Dark Fate review: Linda Hamilton is back on the big screen as Sarah Connor
text:
Pros

Before I touch on anything else in this review, Linda Hamilton is back. She was fantastic in the first two films, and her presence has been greatly missed in all three of the less-than-successful follow-ups. Now finally close to 30 years later, she’s back on the big screen and firing bazookas at robot assassins from the postapocalytic future. For Terminator fans, for sci-fi fans, for Linda Hamilton fans (surprisingly enough) it’s a genuine pleasure to see her again, persuaded no doubt by James Cameron’s return to the producer’s chair.

Mackenzie Davis’ Grace is also very good, really selling her absurdly strong cyborg character and emotionally pulling you into every action scene. You want her to succeed, you want her to save Dani, you want her to survive. There’s some slightly iffy “She needs certain medication to keep her energy up” syringey nonsense, but if you can swallow that, Grace is a stand-out character in the franchise and one you may want to see more of. And just to touch on Arnold himself: he’s not in the film all that much – and it’s a good thing too, as it’s not really his story – but when he’s on screen, it’s a real pleasure to see a long-in-the-tooth Terminator who’s used to human ways, one who has become part of a human family with his absurdly dry jokes. When he says “I am extremely funny”, it really tickled me.

Director Tim Miller is still best known for his break-out hit Deadpool, and when you look at the action scenes in Dark Fate, it’s easy to see why they asked him on board. His VFX background obviously served him well, and there’s some pleasing crunch to his fight choreography. Some of the punches and slices take place as our leads cross the Mexican border into the US, and the political angle of course adds to proceedings. As you’ll see in the Cons section, Dark Fate relies heavily on Judgment Day for its action beats – the new enemy Terminator is essentially a T-800 crossed with a T-1000 – but when it gets going there’s a real thump behind every blow.

Cons

Apologies for being cryptic, but as a fan of the Terminator franchise, some of Dark Fate’s plot decisions are a bit “off” for me. Naturally to reveal them now would potentially ruin the film for you, but trust me, once you’ve seen it you’ll know that there’s one moment in particular that feels wrong, undoing some of the hard work done in Judgment Day. What’s important to remember here is that Terminator 1 and 2 work fine by themselves, and all this is easy to ignore should you wish to, but it’s a shame nonetheless as part of the appeal to this much-delayed threequel is that it picks up the threads of Sarah, John and Skynet and shows you what happened next.

A lot of the headlines popping up around this film scream “The best Terminator film since Judgment Day!” But when you’re a fan of the franchise, you know that isn’t necessarily that big a compliment. It is undeniably true, however, and it’s a relief to watch a Terminator film that is pointed in the right direction, so to speak, leaning hard on what worked before and maintaining that gritty, everything-is-kind-of-awful tone. But sometimes you can lean too hard on past glories and the comparison is not flattering, and this is one of those occasions. It is, in a nutshell, sometimes just too similar to Judgment Day, only not as good. For nostalgia purposes a few nods and callbacks are okay, but robotically recycling certain sequences is an unforced error.

It feels bad to call out one individual actor, but Natalia Reyes was miscast as Dani. Her character has to prop up the whole movie, but I don’t think she hits every mark the film needs her to, particularly towards the end, coming over as a McGuffin the other characters are carrying around for purposes of the plot. Then again, she is ultimately… okay, as is the rest of the film in its own way. It’s clunky and derivative, but it’s also serviceable and occasionally fun, and for a Terminator movie these days, that’s not too bad. And did I mention Linda Hamilton is back? She’s great. And so is Mackenzie Davis!

Three word review: Solid, clunky... fun?
